title: Remote ischaemic preconditioning versus no remote ischaemic preconditioning for vascular and endovascular surgical procedures
authors: Liang, F; Liu, S; Liu, G; Liu, H; Wang, Q; Song, B; Yao, L

response.output:
Ischaemic preconditioning is a technique that may help protect people's bodies from damage during major surgery. But we don't know if it really works and what the risks are.

What is ischaemic preconditioning?
Ischaemic preconditioning is a temporary blockage of blood flow to parts of the body that are not being operated on. This can help protect the body from further damage when blood flow is blocked again during surgery.

What does this review say about ischaemic preconditioning?
This review looked at 14 studies that tested ischaemic preconditioning in people having major vascular or endovascular surgery. The studies compared people who received ischaemic preconditioning with those who did not.

What did the review find?
The review found that ischaemic preconditioning probably makes little or no difference in the risk of death, heart attack, kidney problems, stroke, hospital stay, or operating time. It may also make little or no difference in the risk of losing a limb.

What does this mean for patients?
More research is needed to fully understand the benefits and risks of ischaemic preconditioning. In the meantime, patients should talk to their doctor about what the best approach is for their individual situation.
